definitions.definition: to give something to somebody or allow them to use something that belongs to you, which they have to return to you later
definitions.sensetop: lend somethinglend something to somebodylend out somethinglend out something to somebodylend somebody something

examples.text: They will lend equipment free of charge.
I've lent the car to a friend.
The gallery has been willing to lend out works of art in the past.
The charity lends out laptops to support learning at home.
Can you lend me £10?
Can you lend me your car this evening?
Has he returned that book you lent him?
She very kindly lent me her bicycle.

definitions.definition: to give money to somebody on condition that they pay it back over a period of time and pay interest on it
definitions.sensetop: lend somethinglend somebody somethinglend something to somebodylend (to somebody)

examples.text: The bank lends money at very cheap rates.
They refused to lend us the money.
The bank refused to lend the money to us.
Banks are less willing to lend in these uncertain times.
There are a large number of financial providers lending to businesses across the country.

definitions.definition: to give a particular quality to a person or a situation

examples.text: The setting sun lent an air of melancholy to the scene.
Her presence lent the occasion a certain dignity.

definitions.definition: to give or provide help, support, etc.

examples.text: I was more than happy to lend my support to such a good cause.
He came along to lend me moral support.

definitions.definition: to make something seem true or likely

examples.text: Most of the available evidence lends colour to this view.

definitions.definition: to listen in a patient and kind way to somebody

examples.text: I went over to see if I could lend a hand.

definitions.definition: to let it be known in public that you support or agree with something

examples.text: I am more than happy to lend my name to this campaign.

definitions.definition: to have a place named after you
to make something seem more likely to be true or real

examples.text: This latest evidence lends support to her theory.

wordOrigin: Old English lǣnan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch lenen, also to loan. The addition of the final -d in late Middle English was due to association with verbs such as bend and send.
